data.title: Takeo Nishioka

data.text:
Takeo Nishioka was an important figure in Japanese politics, whose parliamentary career extended over nearly half a century. At the end of his life, he was President of the House of Councillors, the upper house of the Japanese Diet, and the architect of reforms that remained incomplete at his death.

Born in Nagasaki, Nishioka studied at Tokyo’s elite Waseda University, long a training ground for aspiring politicians. He worked as a journalist on a local newspaper in his hometown before entering politics. Elected to the Diet’s lower House of Representatives in 1963, he was to win election to that body another ten times, before entering the upper house in 2001.
